(Calculus) Electric Field of a Uniformly Charged Wire at a Point on the Axis of the Wire

sidebyside.p: A wire of length L carries a uniform charge \lambda (units: \text{C/m}). Find electric field at points (a) \text{P}_1 and (b) \text{P}_2.

hint.p: (a) Use x axis along the wire and find field of an infinitesimal element of the wire. Integrate to get the field. (b) Avoid the field point on the wire by working out field at a point infinitesimally left and at a point infinitesimally to the right.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) Let us place x axis along the wire with origin at one end as shown in . Each charge element on the wire will have only x component of the electric field. For instance, electric field of the element dq = \lambda\; dx will be
dE_x = k \frac{\lambda\; dx}{ \left( L+a-x \right)^2}.

Integrating this from x=0 to x=L will give the net field at \text{P}_1.
E_x \amp= k\lambda\; \int_0^L \frac{dx}{ \left( L+a-x \right)^2} \amp=- k\lambda\; \int_{L+a}^a \frac{dy}{ y^2} \ \ \ (y=L+a-x) \amp= k\lambda\; \left( \frac{1}{a} - \frac{1}{L+a}\right) = k\;\frac{\lambda L}{a(L+a)}.
Note that this is not kq/r^2. If we write q=\lambda L for net charge on the wire and place the entire charge at the center, the field at \text{P}_1 will be
E = k \frac{\lambda L}{ (\frac{L}{2} + a)^2 }.
This is definitely very different from the answer we found for the problem. Only in the limit a \gg L , the two expressions become in indistinguishable.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p: (b) Here we see that electric field of charge on points to the left of \text{P}_2 is pointed to right but points on the right are pointed to left. Using (a), we can write the electric field of left and right separately. But, when we do this calculation naively, by setting a=0 in the answer for (a), you will run into trouble of dividing by zero. To avoid that, we find field at an infintesimal left of \text{P}_2 and infinitesimal right of \text{P}_2.

Let \epsilon denote an infinitesimal length. then, field from the left of \text{P}_2 at a point infintesimal left of \text{P}_2 will be
E_{\text{left},x} = k\lambda\; \left( \frac{1}{\epsilon} - \frac{1}{L}\right)
and at a point infintesimal right of \text{P}_2
E_{\text{right},x} = -k\lambda\; \left( \frac{1}{\epsilon} - \frac{1}{L-b}\right)
Adding them, we find that the arbitrarily chosen infinitesimal size \epsilon cancels out giving us the following, which correctly gives zero for the midpoint.
E_x \amp = E_{\text{left},x} + E_{\text{right},x} = k\lambda \left[ \frac{2b - L}{b(L-b)} \right]

problem.title: Electric Field at the Center of a Charged Circular Arc

sidebyside.p: A non-conducting wire shaped in a half-circle arc of radius R has a uniform charge \lambda. Find the electric field at the center.

hint.p: Place the arc symmetrically about y axis. Work out y field of an element of arc and then integrate.

answer.p: Magnitude \frac{2 k \lambda}{R} in the direction down if charge positive.

sidebyside.p: Let us place the arc symmetrically as shown here. From symmetry about y-axis, net electric field from all elements of the arc will have only y component nonzero.

solution.p:
Therefore, we focus on obtaining y component of one representative element. Magnitude of d\vec E from element of size Rd\theta is relatively easy to see.
dE = k \frac{dq}{R^2} = k \frac{\lambda R d\theta}{R^2}.
Now, we want y component of this. From the figure, we see that it is just multiplied by \sin\theta and -1 since projection is on negative y axis.
dE_z = - k \frac{\lambda R d\theta}{R^2}\ \sin\theta.
We integrate it from \theta=0 to \theta=\pi to get the net field.
E_z \amp = - \frac{k \lambda}{R} \int_0^\pi \sin\theta\: d\theta = -\frac{2 k \lambda}{R}.
Therefore, magnitude is \frac{2 k |\lambda|}{R} and direction is towards negative y axis if charge positive.

problem.title: Electric Field of a Charged Square at a Point above the Center

p.p: A square of side a is charged with uniform charge density of \lambda (units: \text{C/m}).
(a) Find electric field at a distance h above the center of the square.

statement.p: (b) Show that in the limit h \gt \gt a, the formula becomes that of a point charge at the center with charge equal to total charge on the square.

You may make use of the the electric field of a straight wire of length L with charge density \lambda that has the following formula for electric field at a distanc D away from its center.
\vec E_\text{straight} = \hat u\: k \frac{2\lambda L}{ D\sqrt{L^2 + 4D^2}},
where unit vector \hat u is pointed away from the wire.

hint.p: Only vertical component will survive. Find vertical component of the field by one side and multiply by four.

solution.title: (a)

sidebyside.p: (a) Electric field of each side will be in a different direction. But, from symmetry, it is clear that horizontal components of the field from opposite sides of the square will cancel out. Therefore, we just need o work out the vertical component of one wire and multiply by four.

solution.p:
Vertical component will be along z axis in the figure. So, we will just call it as E_z. Now, the distance of P from wire (1) in figure is
D = \sqrt{h^2 + (a/2)^2}.
The z component will be related to the amplitude by \cos\theta.
E_{1z} = E_1\:\cos\theta = E_1\:\frac{h}{D}.
Therefore, with L=a in the formula for magnitude of field from one wire, we can get net electric field at P to be
E_z \amp = 4\times E_{1z} = 4\times E_1\times \frac{h}{D} \amp = 4\times k \frac{2\lambda a}{ D\sqrt{a^2 + 4D^2}} \times \frac{h}{D} = \frac{ 8k\lambda a h }{D^2\sqrt{a^2 + 4D^2}}.
We can replace D with \sqrt{h^2 + (a/2)^2} and simplify to
E_z = \frac{ 8k\lambda a h }{(h^2 + a^2/4)\sqrt{4h^2 + 2a^2}}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
When we take limit a/h \rightarrow 0, we will get the following in the leading order.
E_z = \frac{ 8k\lambda a h }{2h^3} = k\frac{ q }{h^2},
where q=4a\lambda, the total charge on the square. This is the field of a point charge q placed at the center.

problem.title: Electric Field of Two Oppositely Charged Sheets Placed Perpendicularly to Each Other

sidebyside.p: Suppose charges are painted on two large nonconducting sheets so that they have equal charge densities of opposite types, \pm \sigma. Then, the two sheets are placed perpendicularly to each other.

statement.p: You may think of positive sheet being xy plane and the negative sheet as xz plane. Find electric field everywhere.

hint.p: Use superposition of field of each of the two sheets.

problem.title: (Calculus) Electric Field of a Uniformly Charged Finite Cylindrical Drum

sidebyside.p:
A hollow drum of radius R and height h is charged with uniform charge density of \sigma (units: \text{C/m}^2). Consider a point P on the axis of the cylinder. (a) Find electric field at this point. For ease of calculation, place the point outside the cylinder. (b) Show that the electric field can also be written as
\frac{\sigma}{2\epsilon_0} (\sin\theta_1 - \sin\theta_2).

hint.p: Use ring-shaped element and the formula for electric field of the ring to set up dE_z.

solution.title: (a)

sidebyside.p: (a) We will use a ring-shaped element of the drum between z and z+dz. The area of this strip is 2\pi R dz. Therefore, amount of charge in this ring is dq = \sigma \times (2\pi R dz). Since, point P is a distance z_0 - z from this ring, we can immediately write the formla for the z component of electric field at P using the formula for a ring.

solution.p:
dE_z \amp = k\frac{D\; dq}{ \left( R^2 + D^2 \right) } \amp = 2\pi k R \sigma \frac{(z_0-z)\; dz}{ \left( R^2 + (z_0-z)^2 \right) }.
Integrating this from z=0 to z=h gives the net electric field at P. Integration is helped by successive change of variables: (1) change to a=z_0-z, (2) then to b=a^2, and (3) then c=R^2 + b. The final result you should get is
E_z = 2\pi k \sigma \left[ \frac{R}{\sqrt{R^2 + (z_0-h)^2}} - \frac{R}{\sqrt{R^2 + z_0^2}} \right].

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) From the definition of angles \theta_1 and \theta_2, it is clear that
\amp \sin\theta_1 = \frac{R}{\sqrt{R^2 + (z_0-h)^2}}, \amp \sin\theta_2 = \frac{R}{\sqrt{R^2 + z_0^2}}.
We also know that k = 1/4\pi\epsilon_0. Therefore, we get
E_z = \frac{\sigma}{2\epsilon_0}\left( \sin\theta_1 - \sin\theta_2\right).
